docs.lead_paragraph: THE Nasdaq composite is down 59 percent from its peak, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is off almost 20 percent, but ''there are no bargains'' even now, says Warren E. Buffett. ''We're content with what we own, but far from excited by it,'' Mr. Buffett wrote in Berkshire Hathaway's annual report, which was released over the weekend.

headline.main: Market Place; Buffett issues his annual report. Pariahs this year include news media, Wall St. and chief executives.

docs.abstract: Berkshire Hathaway issues annual report in which Warren E Buffett says that there are no bargains around even in today's depressed stock market and that company is content with what it owns, but far from excited about it; praises new SEC regulations barring selective disclosure by corporations, criticizes companies and investors who focus on growth and scores news media for an incorrect report, first published in Wall Street Journal in December, that Berkshire bought high-yield securities issued by Finova and Conseco; Berkshire reports net profit for 2000 of $3.328 billion, up from $1.557 billion in 1999 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman (''Bashing the Boomers,'' column, March 7) has identified the defining issue of the proposed Bush tax cut. Many baby boomers, including those who now have private health insurance, do not realize that at age 65 their primary care will become Medicare.
docs.abstract: Jim Woolsey letter, commenting on Paul Krugman's March 7 column, says federal surplus should not be distributed to the wealthy as a tax cut, but rather used to fortify Social Security and Medicare
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Paul Krugman (''Bashing the Boomers,'' column, March 7) has identified the defining issue of the proposed Bush tax cut. Many baby boomers, including those who now have private health insurance, do not realize that at age 65 their...

docs.lead_paragraph: It had been yet another miserable, nose-dripping, red-eyed spring a couple of years ago, when I finally went to see an allergy specialist. I've been battered by seasonal allergies all my life but relied on family doctors and, more recently, ''primary-care physicians'' for relief. In a kind of a pharmaceutical version of playing catch with Dad, my father and I shared his hay-fever pills when I was growing up. They were smooth, round yellow tablets, etched with a tiny red corporate symbol that was as delicate as a Chinese ideograph. At a time before people routinely gobbled down a half dozen medicines a day, those pills held a kind of mythic power for me, not only because they could make the misery of allergies disappear but also because they were prescription drugs -- inherently more powerful, more inaccessible, more special. Those yellow pills were called Chlor-Trimeton, manufactured by the Schering-Plough Corporation, first as a prescription drug and then, after 1976, as an over-the-counter medication. It definitely worked, but it knocked me out. I remember days when I felt glazed by sleepiness. Even as the high tide in my nose and throat subsided, I felt mentally waterlogged.

headline.main: The Claritin Effect; Prescription for Profit

docs.abstract: Stephen S Hall article details history of Schering-Plough's prescription allergy drug Claritin, holding it reveals why Americans pay premium prices for new drugs that may not be better than older ones; notes aggressively marketed drug is most frequently dispensed drug sample in United States, part of nearly $8 billion worth of free samples that drug companies give to doctors annually; notes drug, designed to relieve symptoms, not offer cure, is only moderately effective at doing so; notes it is sold over-the-counter in many nations at much lower cost; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a 58-year-old vice president at a food company ponders life after retirement, he figures that he will spend time writing his memoirs and doing stand-up comedy, a return to his childhood passion as ''king of the one-liners.'' He also wants to dance. ''It always surprises people that for a short, kind of pudgy guy, I'm a better-than-average ballroom dancer,'' he says.

headline.main: A Practical Guide to Starting Over

docs.abstract: Alecia Swasy reviews Dorothy Cantor's book What Do You Want to Do When You Grow Up?; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, the unthinkable happened in Africa: the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies were forced into a painful negotiation over patent rights and the price of AIDS medicines. Suddenly, the question is no longer whether Africans will get life-saving drug cocktails, but how. That question lacks a simple answer; merely slashing prices will not automatically get drugs to patients. Many African nations are too poor to afford the medicines, even at rock-bottom prices, and some lack the infrastructure to deliver the pills and educate patients about how to use them.
docs.abstract: News analysis of AIDS epidemic in Africa; says now that world's biggest pharmaceutical companies have been forced into painful negotiations over patient rights and price of medicines, question suddenly is no longer whether Africans will get life-saving drug cocktails, but how; many African nations are too poor to afford medicines, even at steeply discounted prices, and some lack infrastructure to deliver drugs and educate patients about how to use them (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite widespread cutbacks in manufacturing, the economy churned out many more jobs last month than Wall Street's forecasters had expected, easing concerns for the moment that the economy is sliding toward recession. The February employment report, released yesterday by the Labor Department, carried a different message: the economy appears to be leveling off, at a weak growth rate, after plunging sharply in the fall and early winter. The collapse in manufacturing has not spread significantly to the rest of the economy.

headline.main: Job Growth Unexpectedly Strong, Easing Recession Fears

docs.abstract: US economy churns out many more jobs in February than Wall Street forecasters expected, easing concerns that economy is sliding toward recession; 135,000 new jobs came despite loss of 95,000 manufacturing jobs; rise in hourly wages is substantial; wide variety of sectors added new jobs; graphs of unemployment and employment (M)
docs.snippet: Despite widespread cutbacks in manufacturing, the economy churned out many more jobs last month than Wall Street's forecasters had expected, easing concerns for the moment that the economy is sliding toward recession.    The February employment...

docs.lead_paragraph: The State of Missouri was feeling generous. The economy was booming; tax dollars were pouring in and legislators decided to use some of the money to expand a modest program that gave a stipend to grandparents acting as foster parents to their grandchildren. But the state did not just expand it a little.

headline.main: Free Spending in Flush Times Is Coming Back to Haunt States

docs.abstract: Many states across the country are over budget after showing lack of fiscal restraint in making commitments to social spending during boom years; state lawmakers, thrown off balance by suddenly sluggish economy, are finding that decisions or promises to spend money when times were flush are coming back to haunt them as tax revenues, particularly from sales tax, decline; National Conference of State Legislatures reports that 31 states are spending more than they budgeted and as many as 23 states may cut budgets or reach into rainy day funds for first time in years; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Capping a four-year drive to unionize California's strawberry workers, the United Farm Workers signed its first contract yesterday with a strawberry grower. The contract covers 750 workers at Coastal Berry, the world's largest strawberry producer, and gives the workers sizable raises and what the union and company called the best health coverage for farm workers in Southern California.

headline.main: Berry Grower Signs Pact With Workers

docs.abstract: United Farm Workers, capping four-year drive to unionize California's strawberry workers, signs its first contract with a strawberry grower; contract covers 750 workers at Coastal Berry, world's largest strawberry producer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE we go again. By rescinding a new set of ergonomic regulations, Congress this week raised an old question: do the workers of the world need politicians and union leaders to write safety rules for them? It's a touchy issue, as I discovered from the large pile of hate mail that arrived after a column in 1999 about the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire. I questioned the popular view, as expressed in a documentary by Ric Burns, that the 1911 fire inspired ''epoch making'' reforms protecting ''hapless'' workers against ''nightmarish'' exploitation by employers.

headline.main: The Big City; Best Incentive For Job Safety: Money

docs.abstract: John Tierney The Big City column maintains, in wake of Congress's repeal of ergonomic regulations, that workplace safety rules are impotent and that job safety is profitable; speaks from his experience with repetitive stress injury and treatment he received at expense of his employer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A coalition of health care and union officials that successfully pushed last year for the largest expansion of Medicaid coverage ever in New York State has turned its attention to nursing homes, with the hope of eliciting millions more in state Medicaid money to increase staffing in the homes. That coalition is composed of members of 1199/S.E.I.U., the state's largest health care union, and executives from the Greater New York Hospital Association, an industry group. It is seeking an increase of $100 million in Medicaid money for recruiting and hiring more nurses and other staff members for the state's 676 nursing homes.

headline.main: Group to Push for New Money for Nursing Home Staffing

docs.abstract: Healthcare Education Project, coalition of health care and union officials that successfully pushed last year for largest expansion of Medicaid coverage ever in New York State, has turned its attention to nursing homes, with hope of eliciting millions more in state Medicaid money to increase staffing in homes (M)
